intro: Cleistesiopsis × ochlockneensis, commonly known as the Texas morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States. It belongs to the Convolvulaceae family and is characterized by its trumpet-shaped, showy flowers that typically bloom in the early morning. The plant is a perennial vine that can grow up to several meters in length, with heart-shaped leaves and hairy stems. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, often found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides and fields. Its rapid growth and ornamental value make it both a popular garden plant and a potential weed.
